Print Email Font Resize business CineMedia reels in ads By Andy Vuong The Denver Post denverpost.com Posted: 12/02/2007 01:00:00 AM MST Kurt Hall, National CineMedia's CEO, works out of the company's network operations center in Centennial.(Brian Brainerd, The Denver Post ) CENTENNIAL—From the company's network operations center, National CineMedia engineers can see which commercials are being shown, and in what order, to moviegoers. Staffed 24 hours a day, the center closely monitors a digital network that beams advertisements via satellite to computer servers at more than 950 movie theaters, including 26 in Colorado. The network is the linchpin for a company that has helped transform cinema advertising, an industry booming amid the marketing shift from traditional broadcast and print media. "The beauty and the power of our network is this combination of being able to distribute nationally and target locally," said National CineMedia chief executive Kurt Hall. "The digital network has National CineMedia employs 500 people, including 350 in Colorado. Denver financier Philip Anschutz holds a large ownership stake.( Brian Brainerd, The Denver Post ) really allowed advertisers to treat cinema ... very much like television. The lead times are somewhat similar. They have the ability to change out ads whenever they want." National CineMedia, which launched 2 1/2 years ago as a joint venture among the nation's three largest theater chains, has deep ties to Qwest Communications founder Philip Anschutz. The Denver financier holds a large ownership stake but is not involved in the company's operations. Cinema advertising was once relegated to being shown on the same 35-millimeter film as the movies themselves, which is more costly and time-consuming to distribute. That also made it difficult for an advertiser to change or update a commercial. With satellites installed on the roofs of each of the theaters in its network, National CineMedia can easily distribute and make changes to its First Look program, the roughly 25-minute preshow that includes four commercial segments and behind-the-scenes previews of movies and TV shows. The network allows advertisers to pick the theater locations and movies they want to target. They can even target by a movie's rating. Major cinema advertisers include the military, automobile and entertainment industries, although a number of new industries are testing the medium. In the third quarter, J.C. Penney became the first department store to run ads during First Look, and Wendy's was the first fast-food restaurant, said Eric Handler, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, which has had an investment banking relationship with National Cine Media in the past year. While still just a small fraction of the overall advertising industry, cinema marketing revenues grew from $357.5 million in 2004 to $455.7 million in 2006, a 27 percent increase, according to the Cinema Advertising Council. During the same time frame, broadcast advertising grew by about 6 percent and newspaper advertising declined slightly, according to the Television Bureau of Advertising. "New" advertising "There's clearly a lot of money moving out of existing mediums, whether it's television, radio, newspaper, toward the Internet, toward cinema, toward what I'll call new advertising platforms that are being developed," Hall said. "We're one of those platforms. We're benefiting from that movement of money out of those other mediums in just the same way Goog le is benefiting from that." Specifically, television advertising has been hurt by the growing use of digital video recorders, which allow viewers to skip through commercials. "What's going on right now in the overall advertising market, in terms of video advertising, is television continues to face an eroding audience base," Handler said. Cinema advertising is more effective because "once you're in your seat, you can't change your channel," Handler said. "You're pretty much sitting there and you see the program and it's on this big 40-foot screen." Wall Street welcomed National CineMedia's initial public offering in February. Shares sold for $21, above the pre-IPO target price of $18 to $20 a share. Nine of 12 analysts tracked by Bloomberg financial services have a "buy" rating on the stock, which closed Friday at $27.68 a share. Two have a "sell" rating and one has a "hold." Shareholders own a 44 percent stake in the company, and the three founding partners—Regal Entertainment Group, AMC and Cinemark—hold a 56 percent stake. The three theater chains' joint venture created a national footprint for what was once "a highly fragmented industry," Handler said. "These three players, when combined, have a national footprint that covers about 50 percent of all screens in the United States," Handler said. Crisis and opportunity The groundwork for this network was laid from 2000 to 2002, when the opportunistic Anschutz swooped in amid an industry crisis. After rushing to build megaplexes with stadium-style seating in the late 1990s, operators were left with an overcapacity of screens and a heavy debt burden. Anschutz spent less than $500 million acquiring the debt of Regal, United Artists and Edwards Theatres Circuit on the cheap, and gained control of the companies when they each filed for bankruptcy protection. Anschutz combined the companies, later adding the Hoyts chain, to create the largest theater operator in the nation, Regal Entertainment Group. Hall, formerly the head of United Artists, was appointed co-CEO of Regal to focus on boosting the company's revenue, while his counterpart, Mike Campbell, was assigned to focus on existing operations. "My main job was to look for other things to do with the asset," said Hall, 48. In March 2005, Regal combined its advertising arm with AMC's to create National CineMedia, which employs 500 people, including 350 in Colorado. Cinemark, the nation's third-largest theater chain, joined as a founding member later that year. Anschutz is the majority owner of Regal, which holds roughly a 23 percent stake in National CineMedia. Medium offers message In addition to advertising, National CineMedia has two much smaller business divisions—CineMeetings and NCM Fathom. CineMeetings works to fill off-peak theater hours—essentially Monday through Thursday—with corporate events and meetings. "If you're delivering a message or something like that, it's a really good medium to do that, especially if you have offices in multiple cities," said Mike Hickey, an analyst with Janco Partners in Greenwood Village. "It's a lower margin business ... but I absolutely believe that that's a real opportunity for them." Companies that are using theaters as meeting spaces include Burger King and Microsoft. NCM Fathom distributes to its theaters concerts, sporting events and other live and recorded entertainment content, such as the Metropolitan Opera and St. Olaf Christmas Festival. The bulk of National CineMedia's revenue comes from the advertising arm. The company has one primary competitor, privately held Screenvision. Analysts say National CineMedia is likely to emerge as the industry's leader. "It's kind of a duoply, and National CineMedia appears to be the clear champ," Hickey said. Both companies have about the same number of total screens, roughly 14,000, but National CineMedia will take the lead next year when Loews Cineplex and Kerasotes Theatres join its network. Kerasotes is switching from Screenvision. National CineMedia has 30-year deals with the theaters in its network, while Screenvision's deals are much shorter, Handler said. "There's always the potential for National CineMedia to pick off the top affiliates of Screenvision," Handler said. National CineMedia's digital network covers 12,600 of its 14,000 screens. By the first quarter of next year, Screenvision will have 7,000 digital screens, according to chief executive Matthew Kearney. Kearney notes that Screenvision has several marquee independent theater chains in its network, such as California's Pacific Theatres and Mann Theatres. Screenvision's network includes 34 theaters in Colorado. "We are both winning dollars from other advertising platforms," Kearney said.
National CineMedia
Headquarters: Centennial
Chief executive: Kurt Hall Employees: 500, including 350 in Colorado Founded: March 2005 IPO price: $21 a share (Feb. 7) Stock price: $27.68 Ticker symbol: NCMI Market capitalization: $1.16 billion Revenue: $213.7 million (since IPO to quarter ended Sept. 27) Net income: $16.6 million (same period) Ownership: Public shareholders own 44 percent of the company while the nation's three largest theater chains—Regal, AMC and Cinemark—own the rest. The company was initially formed as a joint venture among the three theater operators. Andy Vuong: 303-954-1209 or avuong@denverpost.com Copyright 2012 The Denver Post. All rights reserved.
